description:
Human betaherpesvirus 6A (HHV-6A) is a species of DNA virus that belongs to the Betaherpesvirinae subfamily of the Herpesviridae family. It is a double-stranded DNA virus that primarily infects human cells, with a particular tropism for CD4+ T-lymphocytes.

HHV-6A is considered one of the human herpesviruses, and it is closely related to, but distinct from, the closely related species Human betaherpesvirus 6B (HHV-6B). Both HHV-6A and HHV-6B are ubiquitous, with the majority of the human population becoming infected with one or both variants during childhood.

The primary mode of transmission for HHV-6A is believed to be through saliva, and the virus can establish a latent infection within the host's cells. Reactivation of the latent virus can occur under conditions of immunosuppression or stress, leading to various clinical manifestations, including febrile illness, encephalitis, and in some cases, an association with certain neurological and autoimmune disorders.

Ongoing research continues to explore the epidemiology, pathogenesis, and potential clinical implications of HHV-6A infection, as well as the development of diagnostic tests and potential therapeutic interventions for managing HHV-6A-related diseases.
